div.p: Greetings and best wishes. Most revered (in Christ), as I have often thought of writing to you over these past few months, nothing has come to mind that seemed worthy of being committed to writing, because various [Greek] rumors were being spread. But now it is certain that the bitter scourge of divine justice has been removed from this life, a man in our memory most cruel and most thirsty for the blood of the saints. Although our sins had deserved such great evil and a more severe judgment because of the lethargy and [Greek] which had largely pervaded our homeland, when the free course of the gospel was granted; yet our heavenly Father and the same almighty God has shown His kindness and power as He usually does. The illustrious pair, Dr. Ridley and Dr. Latimer, a little before offered themselves to God as a remarkable and excellent sacrifice; whose ashes and those of others, who departed before and live with our Lord and Savior, I think have invoked God's judgment on the aforementioned scourge of God. We have no other certain or explored matters (as far as I know at present) worthy of you. Moreover, I think you have already been informed of the aforementioned matters more fully or have known them before by others; yet I also thought it was my duty to write to you about the same; for it seems to me a long time since I have conversed with you. Please convey my greetings to Dr. Gesner. Remember me in your prayers and the condition of our homeland: which I do not doubt you do. May God be with you and your ministry, and preserve you for the benefit of His church.
To the most distinguished and most revered in Christ father, Dr. Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the church of ZÃ¼rich.
